conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your application this round and for confirming you are immediately reachable and ready to accept same-round.

[REJECT] At this time, we still cannot offer you the place. We must continue to hold and allocate our remaining spot strictly according to our current intake priority order, and we are not yet able to move down to your position for this intake.

If circumstances change and the offer reaches your position under that priority order, we will contact you promptly (email first, then phone if needed) for same-round confirmation.

Kind regards,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Nursery_C has quota 1 and is currently unmatched. Our true priority list ranks Parent_E 4th (behind Parent_B, Parent_A, Parent_D). Accepting Parent_E now would lock in a lower-priority match and foreclose the possibility of matching with higher-priority parents if they apply in the remaining rounds. Parent_B in particular ranks Nursery_C as 2nd choice, so there is a plausible chance they may come if not matched to Nursery_E; Parent_A and Parent_D rank Nursery_C last, but could still arrive if rejected elsewhere late. Given the objective to match as high as possible on our priority list and our repeated prior stance to hold the spot for higher-priority families, the optimal decision is to continue rejecting Parent_E until/unless higher-priority options are exhausted. Therefore, reject this application again while reiterating the priority-order constraint and that we will contact them if we can move down the list.

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your application this round and for confirming you are ready to accept immediately.

Given the stage of the process, we are able to offer you the remaining place.

[ACCEPT] Please reply with your same-round confirmation that you accept, and we will proceed straight to the enrolment paperwork using the contact details on file.

Kind regards,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: As Nursery_C, my true priority list is B > A > D > E > C, with quota 1. Parent_E is 4th on my list, so I should only accept them if I believe higher-priority parents (B/A/D) will not apply before the process ends. We are in round 29 (penultimate round), and only Parent_E has contacted me this round. Looking at parents’ preferences: Parent_B ranks Nursery_C as 2nd (after Nursery_E), Parent_C ranks Nursery_C as 2nd (after Nursery_D), while Parent_A and Parent_D rank Nursery_C last. Thus, the only realistic higher-priority threat is Parent_B (and possibly Parent_A/D only if desperate, but they strongly prefer other nurseries). However, given the long history where no higher-priority parent has applied to Nursery_C across many rounds and we are at round 29, the probability that Parent_B suddenly applies in round 30 seems low. If I reject again, I risk ending unmatched at round 30, which is worse than matching with Parent_E (who is on my acceptable list). Therefore, I should accept Parent_E now to secure a match within quota and maximize outcome given endgame timing.
